So much money is 
      being spent in Iraq to 
      fight the insurgency and keep the country running that there are bound to 
      be millions that fall through the cracks. But could one or a few 
      individuals have made off with half a billion dollars? As 
      correspondent Steve 
      Kroft reports on our lead story, somebody apparently 
      did, making this robbery “the mother of all heists.”  The money was 
      supposed to equip the new Iraqi military, instead, say Iraqi 
      investigators, it was stolen by the very people the U.S. government had entrusted to run 
      Iraq’s Ministry of Defense. And 
      they just  might get away with it. The whole business has become a 
      can of worms, says  Kroft: “Neither the United 
      States nor its allies have much of an 
      appetite for pursuing it.”
 
Watch Steve Kroft's reporter's 
      notebook.
 
 
How wonderful would it be if 
      you could just take a pill to take the sting out of bad memories? To 
      the victims of post traumatic stress disorder, it would truly be a 
      breakthrough. In fact, correspondent Lesley Stahl’s report on a new 
      use of an old drug suggests there is such a pill that could help 
      millions. Our story also looks into the ethical questions 
      involved. If such a drug were to be put on the market, would it 
      be limited to severe trauma victims, or, as critics say, would the 
      pharmaceutical industry try to profit by encouraging its use for a wide 
      array of situations? It would seem the perfect treatment for a rape 
      victim, but what about for a painful breakup or even a bad day at the 
      office?  One ethicist tells Stahl those kinds of bad memories 
      are integral to who we are: "They make us better people."
 
Watch Lesley Stahl's reporter's 
      notebook.
 
 
John Daly is the bad boy of 
      golf. He trains on a steady diet of fast food, cigarettes and beer. But 
      that’s only the tip of the iceberg when it comes to Daly’s bad boy habits. 
      Daly tells correspondent Morley Safer, “I was a basket case you 
      know? When I got mad, I threw clubs…And if things weren’t going well, I 
      would walk off a course."
 
See these 
      stories and whether Andy Rooney is an "A" 
      or a "B" personality, this Sunday, June 17, on 60 Minutes 
      at 7 p.m. ET/PT.
